text:
Katherine Roberts Maher (born April 18, 1983) is the chief executive officer and executive director of the Wikimedia Foundation.
Before this, she was their chief communications officer.
Early life and education.
Maher grew up in Wilton, Connecticut.
She went to Wilton High School.
In 2003, Maher graduated from the Arabic Language Institute's Arabic Language Intensive Program of The American University in Cairo. Maher subsequently studied at the in Syria. During this period, she also spent time in Lebanon and Tunisia.
In 2005, Maher received a bachelor's degree from New York University in Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies.
Career.
From 2007 to 2010, Maher worked at UNICEF as an innovation and communication officer.
She focused on the use of technology to improve people's lives. Maher worked on issues related to maternal health, AIDS prevention, and youth participation in technology.
One of her first projects at UNICEF involved testing MediaWiki extensions related to accessibility in Ethiopia.
From 2010 to 2011, Maher worked at the National Democratic Institute as an ICT Program Officer.
From 2011 to 2013, Maher worked as an ICT innovation specialist at the World Bank.
In 2012, Maher's Twitter feed on issues related to the Middle East was cited as being notable in its coverage of the Arab Spring.
From 2013 to 2014, Maher was advocacy director at the Washington, D.C.-based Access Now. As part of this work, she focused on the impact on people of laws about cyber security, morality, and defamation of the state that increase state censorship and reduce dissent. Access was a signatory of the Declaration of Internet Freedom.
Wikimedia Foundation.
From April 2014 to March 2016, Maher was chief communications officer of the Wikimedia Foundation. During this time, she gave an interview in "The Washington Post" on United States copyright law.
In March 2016, Maher became interim executive director of the Wikimedia Foundation following the resignation of then executive director, Lila Tretikov. Maher was appointed executive director in June 2016. The appointment was announced by Jimmy Wales on June 24, 2016 at Wikimania 2016 in Esino Lario, Italy, effective June 23, 2016.
Maher states that she focuses on global digital inclusion as a way to improve and protect the rights of people to information through technology.
Personal life.
Maher is based in San Francisco, California. Besides English, she also speaks Arabic, French, and German.
